title: 114_hr2899
content: The "Countering Violent Extremism Act of 2015" or the "CVE Act" authorizes the Office for Countering Violent Extremism within the Department of Homeland Security. The Countering Violent Extremism Act of 2015 establishes the Office for Countering Violent Extremism within the Department of Homeland Security. The head of the Office is the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, appointed by the Secretary, who also appoints a career Deputy Assistant Secretary for the same purpose. Personnel with technical, media, communications, or marketing backgrounds are sought for the Office. The Secretary of Homeland Security seeks individuals with technical, media, communications, or marketing backgrounds for the Office for Countering Violent Extremism. Personnel will be appointed within various components and offices of the Department, including U.S. Customs and Border Protection, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, and others. The Secretary of Homeland Security is looking for individuals with technical, media, communications, or marketing backgrounds to serve as liaisons to the Office for Countering Violent Extremism. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will coordinate the Department's activities to counter violent extremism across all components and offices conducting strategic and supportive activities in this area. The Department of Homeland Security is coordinating activities to counter violent extremism by identifying risk factors and populations targeted by extremist propaganda. The Department of Homeland Security is focusing on identifying populations targeted by violent extremist propaganda, managing outreach activities towards at-risk communities, and ensuring relevant information informs efforts to counter violent extremism. The Department of Homeland Security is developing a strategy to counter violent extremism, including a counter-messaging program leveraging technology. The Department of Homeland Security is developing a counter-messaging program to leverage technology and social media platforms to counter violent extremism. The Department of Homeland Security is engaging with various partners in counter-messaging activities to counter violent extremism. This includes outreach activities, cooperative agreements with different government entities, and ensuring all related activities are coordinated effectively. The Department of Homeland Security is responsible for countering violent extremism and ensuring activities respect privacy and civil liberties. The Department of Homeland Security is developing outcome-based metrics to evaluate programs and policies for countering violent extremism. They are also identifying new research requirements and ensuring information dissemination to relevant authorities. The Department of Homeland Security is working on outcome-based metrics to evaluate programs for countering violent extremism and establishing a counter-messaging program to combat propaganda and messaging by violent extremists. The Department of Homeland Security is establishing a counter-messaging program to combat propaganda by violent extremists, utilizing social media platforms and coordinating with other federal agencies and non-governmental organizations. The Department of Homeland Security is coordinating with the Department of State on international countering violent extremism issues and providing guidance on the use of grants for countering violent extremism to State, local, and tribal governments. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will coordinate with the Federal Emergency Management Agency to administer grants for countering violent extremism, outlined in a memorandum of understanding. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will establish a grant program in coordination with the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties of the Department. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with FEMA and the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, will establish a grant program for community groups to create counter-messaging campaigns against violent extremism. An implementation plan must be developed within 90 days of enactment. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with FEMA and the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, will provide an implementation plan for a grant program within 90 days of enactment. Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate will provide an implementation plan for a grant program, including eligibility and application criteria, methodology for awarding grants, and monitoring and evaluating grant applications and awards. A community group or organization is ineligible for a grant if they have funded violent extremist activities, as determined by the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism. The Assistant Secretary will submit an annual report to Congress on the Office for Countering Violent Extremism for the next five fiscal years. The Assistant Secretary will submit annual reports to Congress for the next five fiscal years on the Department's programs and policies for countering violent extremism in the United States, including budget and staffing details. The annual reports to Congress will include details on the number of full-time and part-time employees dedicated to countering violent extremism programs, funding amounts for departmental initiatives, and outcome-based metrics used for assessing program effectiveness. Additionally, the reports will describe the Office's activities in cooperating with other departments and agencies. The annual reports to Congress will include details on the Office's activities to cooperate with other departments and agencies, outcome-based metrics for evaluating program success, organizations engaged in countering violent extremism, grants awarded, and training conducted. The Department conducted outreach with organizations to discuss countering violent extremism, awarded grants for this purpose, provided training, analyzed personnel and funding needs for the Office, assessed activities in response to the threat environment, and summarized the focus on civil rights and civil liberties. The Department's activities to counter violent extremism are analyzed, focusing on adapting to the threat environment, protecting civil rights and liberties, evaluating grant programs, and incorporating lessons from other departments and agencies. The Office of the Secretary allocated $10,000,000 for countering violent extremism annually. "Violent extremism" is defined as ideologically motivated terrorist activities.
